description:
I came on a weekday about 6pm.  There are BIG tables there where it seems families and large groups come together for events like birthday parties, events, etc.  A fourth of their menu is even devoted to serving groups of people.  I was only 1 person and there weren't any 1-person tables, only 4-person or more tables, so you should definitely BOOKMARK Empero for LARGE groups like Family/Relatives if you want a bargain in SF for large groups!!  However, they also have lunch specials for individuals.

I only ordered the French pork spare ribs($10.98)[reviewers Jason C on December 20, 2017 and Cathy W on April 7, 2012 have good pics of French pork spareribs]  with white rice(after seeing the great reviews on this entrée, I was eager to taste it!).  !  After reading the reviews about how much food they gave, I also didn't want to order too much that I couldn't eat.  Not everything's on the menu like iced water, drinks & desserts, so you should ask them if you want those items.  They also have a $10 minimum for using your CC.

At the start, they also gave me a pot of green tea and a small cup of soup which tasted very nourishing with small scraps of potatoes, carrots, and meat which reminded me of my mom's soups which wasn't just hot water with a few tossed scraps tossed in like most Asian restaurants.  Instead, it tasted like it had been cooked slowly for a long time and the small bits of vegetables & meat were so tender, truly a real nourishing tasty broth-like soup.  I usually hate soups since they're just hot water that fill me up too much before the entrees, but this was one "soup" I finished with relish!  This reminds me of what the classic Chinese restaurants were about, not just what was on the menu but a whole dining experience which may have included a pot of tea, mini appetizers, mini soups, mini salads, etc. before your actual entrée dishes came.

Let me get on my rickety soapbox about fried rice in most Asian restaurant menus.  I am ASTOUNDED by seeing $8 to over $10 for fried rice in most Asian restaurants.  Fried rice originally as all Asians know is supposed to be about saving last night's leftover rice for the purpose of eating it the next day. Asians are frugal with food and don't believe in just throwing away food.   Well, to "revive" or make leftover cold hard rice more appetizing to eat, Asians had to reheat it in the frypan (usually a high walled wok pan to keep the rice from spilling out) with cheap or free ingredients added from yesterday's leftover chicken, meat, etc along with any chopped veggies you saw in your refridge .  If there were no leftovers, you added spam or scrambled eggs, bacon, etc.  And you added butter, msg, salt & pepper and whatever spice you wanted for seasonings.  All of this was made at home for the price of basically NEAR $0 since the WHOLE PURPOSE was to NOT THROW AWAY LEFTOVERS.

But now at Asian restaurants, you're paying $10 or more for fried rice??!!  OK, I get that they use a lot of animal protein and their rice is fresh steamed (not leftovers), but they should divide the fried rice into 2 groups with one being LIGHT SIDE DISH fried rice which should be just mainly cheap vegetables & seasoning & tiny amounts of meat or just eggs(maybe call it house fried rice) and so the cost should be $5 or lower!!  The other group of fried rice should be ENTRÉE fried rice for people who want all that animal protein & premium ingredients and want it more as a MAIN MEAL, rather than as a side(even though there's already lots of meat in the entrée dishes) and THAT'S what should cost over $10!!  To me, it just doesn't make sense paying over $5 for a side that's supposed to be a leftover!!  To me, it's like eating something you could make cheaply & easily at home especially when you have leftover rice in abundance!! :)-  It's like people have lost the desire to cook simple foods and have surrendered their cents & senses(yes, pun) to restaurants & corporations.  I LAUGH and WALK ON BY the supermarket's PF CHANG'S frozen fried rice for near $10!!  LOL  Yeah, like I'm willing to hand over real money just to get FROZEN fried rice with a SMALL SMATTERING of chicken or shrimp!!  

............Back to our regular scheduled program............

The servers were nice and prompt.  Their French pork spare ribs is very different from the usual Chinese ribs.  The French pork spare ribs has more meat than bone, but the meat is sliced thin to easily eat & cook tender, although you have to make sure to not swallow the small bone part.  .  The texture is slightly crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside, sweet but with tangy spices along with the sweetness. And they give you A LOT!!  This was served on a bed of lettuce, a couple of sliced tomatoes & cucumbers.  Even if you only had a light lunch, 1 entrée will be more than enough for 1 person!!  There's lots of street parking.
author: Frugal C.

description:
My family and I made reservation for 16 for my moms birthday at 7pm. This means two tables. When we make reservation, we expect the two tables to be ready at 7 when we come. But it was not. We prolly didn't get seated at the tables until 7:30!

Aside from the disorganization, the food was pretty decent. My family and I order a lot of stuff separately.  The lobster noodle was the best in my opinion! I also love the sizzling rice soup! I recommend ordering the food separately and not the family plan set meal! We got a lot of stuff and it turned out to be less than the family meal.
author: Shw L.

description:
Family ordered a la carte and found everything to be pretty good - not too salty and quantity plentiful.

We started off our meal with some house soup which was good for warming up our tummies on a windy SF night. Next came the garlic pea sprouts and some stir fried bean sprouts with beef cubes. The pea sprouts were a little older (tougher) but still had a nice crispness to them. As for the stir fry, the bean sprouts were crunchy and the beef was tender - I'd recommend this dish.

Following this came our dishes of three mushrooms and tofu and dried bean curd with rock cod filets. Both were good in my opinion, but definitely way too much gravy for both. Following this came our order of mushu chicken. The wrappers were absolutely abysmal in my opinion - stuck together and oversteamed/dry. But where the wraps failed, the stir fried filling was done nicely. This dish was also very hefty for just 6 wrappers. We didn't hesitate to take home the leftovers and simply combined it with noodles for a "new" dish.

For rice, we had dried scallop and egg white fried rice. I found it too true to the name, it only had dried scallops and egg white. Typically, it would also include scallions and the ends of gai lan, which adds a nice fragrance and crunch to the dish. Oh well.

Dessert was complementary and it was taro dessert with clear tapioca. YUM. One of my favorites!
author: Elaine Y.

description: This was my first real experience with Cantonese food, and it was a good one. If you're used to "American" Chinese food, do not expect a meal at all similar to that. My group came in for lunch and we were seated immediately. Our table ordered family style and the locals with us chose all the dishes. It all tasted very fresh and well seasoned. I think our spread could have used a little (lot) more seafood after noticing all that they serve while checking on here, but I suppose not everyone loves seafood as much as me. My table consisted of people literally from all over the world/country and everyone loved it. All is served on a rotating platform on the table, so make sure your friend across the table is done getting the food on their plate before you start spinning it! Or this could be a very useful tactic in keeping as much of the Cantonese goodness for yourself. Whoever can spin the spinner fastest wins, and everyone else leaves hungry. Muahaha!
author: Dakota C.

description:
My family (plus some extended fam and friends) was doing a dinner on a random Wednesday and picked Empero Taste. Everyone was already here when I arrived on May 16th around 6:30pm. Not sure if we had a reservation, but we were a party of 12 people.

$238 for 10:
*Fish Maw & Seafood Soup
*Prawns & Chicken with Green
*Abalone with Green
*Clams in Black Bean Sauce
*Spicy Salted Prawns with Shell
*Lobster E-Fu Noodle
*Steamed Queen Empress Chicken
*Salt & Pepper Spareribs
*Steamed Live Black Bass
*Yan Chow Fried Rice

We got the menu above, but I think we got the French Style Pork Spareribs instead of the salt & pepper and a Whole Fried Fish instead of the steamed one. I actually didn't care for our replacements as I found the french spareribs too sweet. I adore the steamed prep of fish, so I was bummed we didn't get it. It's actually one of my favorite dishes. Out of the rest of the dishes, my favs were the chicken, abalone, and rice. The chicken was moist and silky. The abalone had a nice chew. I also enjoyed the broccoli that came with it. I'm normally not a big rice person, but the yang chow chao fan was fried nicely and had a good amount of shrimp, pork, etc. The salt and pepper prawns were also fried nicely with good savory spicy notes. The lobster was good, but the yi mein was way too soggy. Very mushy. The soup and shrimp/chicken dish were average. The soup could have used some more seasoning.

*Chicken Soup with Cordyceps Flower
*Ginger and Green Onion Crab
*Salt and Pepper Fried Crab
*Chinese Bacon and Preserved Green

Since I come from a family of gluttons, we also added the items above. Both crabs were a good size. I'm a fan of the ginger scallion prep, so I enjoyed that one more. The salt & pepper one was pretty good too. Came with a good amount of fried bits of meat and peppers. I'm not big on the soup or the pork dishes above, so I found both to be okay. The soup was a bit too sweet for me. I'm not into stewed meats, so I found the bacon mushy. To finish our meal, we also got a green bean dessert. Standard for all chinese dinners.

We bought a bottle of wine to accompany dinner (I believe for $12) and a few bowls of rice, so overall, I think our bill totaled $349.22. Not bad for all the dishes we ordered. Great place for good quality cheap eats.
author: Elena N.

description:
Hidden gem of outer richmond.

This place is not a fancy Chinese restaurant, heck it's far from it but it does standard Cantonese fare well and at times with a twist.

The highlight was the seafood crispy chow mein.  The ingredients are not of the best quality, but the skill and attention to detail shines through. For example the oil used to fry the noodles made the noodles itself very tasty. The noodles are also spread out onto the plate with the meat and veggies in the middle. Instead of a regular dish, it's served in a large plate so the gravy drains towards the middle. What ends up happening is that you get crispy noodles through out the meal as the gravy stays in the middle keeping the noodles crispy. Just this simple technique and plate made this chow mein more enjoyable than places cost 2 to 3 more!

Another standout was the French style spare ribs. It was a cross between your typical sweet and sour spare ribs and the salt and pepper spare ribs. It's sweet savory and deeply garlicky. 

We also got the clay pot tofu seafood and pork belly with preserve veggies. Both were also prepared well. The fresh lettuce gave the pork belly a contrasting crunch. 

It's awesome to find an excellent inexpensive Chinese place done well. Chef's ability trump all. Skill hands can turn boring to awesome!
author: Jason C.

description: My go to restaurant for Cantonese style Chinese food. Consistently good, quick service. I order food to go a lot, especially coming back from vacation. Nothing beats home style Chinese food!
author: Regina G.

description:
Came here for basic family dinner the other night. Was able to score parking too! It's difficult some times to find parking because of the residential neighborhood. Can we talk about the Engrish of the name though..."empero" clearly someone forgot a "r" at the end 

The food here is good, and it it a hit or miss depending on what you order. Can't vouch for the entire menu, but will say what we did order: 

Fried flounder: great! Lightly battered and not oily. Some other establishments you can tell the oil is not fresh due to the color on the item. Here, was not a problem. 

Giant clams with noodles: love this dish! It's about $10+ for each giant clam and it's split in half. My mom can make this at home too, but access to the giant clam is not a guarantee. Love that the cellophane noodles soak up all the sauce. 

French styles pork chops: AMAZING! I definitely recommend this, particularly since I haven't seen it at any other menus. The fragrant taste is attributable to the fried basil. This is better than any "Peking" style ribs. 

Chinese broccoli with squid: a good veggie dish with a good amount of everything. 

The restaurant overall is a good value. Don't expect great service.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I come here on occasion and the food here is always phenomenal. It's always hot and fresh as well as quick. The portion size are great and we always order family style. Everything I've had on the menu from deep fried to boiled and fresh are always scrumptious. 

Favorites are the oyster and black bean clams. Their salt and pepper pork ribs and pawns are also really good. I think my favorite will be the fried green beans with fish. They deep fry the fish and green beans then they do a stir fry all together. it's great with rice and I love it for leftovers. 

Other things they do well are their Singapore noodles and beef chow fun. I really enjoy coming here and they are so friendly. I look forward to visiting when I can.
author: Leme K.

description: First, this is a no frills Chinese restaurant in the Richmond District, and probably the only one that have a decent size dining area for special days like Mother's Day. On special days and the day prior this place gets busy. So busy they service decreases dramatically. We had a party of 30 (three tables), one table never received water like throughout the whole dinner. The only table did not get one of the orders (choy). We ordered three of everything for each table. Of the 7 items we ordered for the three tables, most did not come out the same time so we ended up sharing plates across the able rather than have one table wait for their order. Some took 20 minutes longer than others. Basically, coming here when it's busy mean lot more patience is required. The food is good. The hot plate plate beef, ribs and catfish were the best. The stuffed chicken with sticky rice is very filling and one order could've feed all three tables. Everything here is old and parking is horrible but it is a great place to enjoy family dinners.
author: Gerald H.

description: The food and services are not prefect. But hard to beat the price. I and my family come every weekend for dinner. We like their seafood especially the lobster. Most of their dishes are decent.
author: Keung M.

description: My favorite dish is French style pork chop which has the most unique taste of basil & tender pork chop.  If you prefer salted fish, don't miss their salted fish chicken fried rice. BTW, very generous portion for lunch dish.
author: Wendy W.

description:
Came here looking for some good Chinese and this turned out to be pretty decent spot.  First off the restaurant was nice, clean, and similar to many other Chinese spots I've been too.  Staff was super quick and courteous.   

We ordered fried rice, garlic bok Choi, sizzling Mongolian beef, mapo tofu, and vegetarian combination.  The sizzling Mongolian beef was by far my favorite but everything was very well cooked and seasoned.  The dinner meals all came with a pork based soup which was okay.  The portions were huge and the food was tasty.  At the end they brought out a dessert item, wasn't sure what it was, and it had an interesting taste but we ate it anyway.  

Is definitely come back here since the food was good, plentiful, and the price was right.
author: Dan O.

description: This restaurant is hands down on of the best for the value. The food is consistently good over the years. I have been coming here for many years and take out quite a bit. I have never had a bad dish either take out or dine in. Good food and reasonably priced! Love it here.
author: Sam H.

description:
This is a favorite place of my mother's for take out. I find their food inconsistent. 

The shrimp fried rice is good. Beef chow fun is hit or miss and needs hot pepper oil to make it edible. The chicken won ton soup was in the salty side.
author: michelle l.

description: My mother likes this place, the food is pretty good and the price is reasonable. I highly recommend the dinner packages they offer. The lobster noodles and Peking duck was delicious.
author: Daniel C.

description:
OMG !!!
Where is the chicken?!!!
All flour and no chicken!!!

Called to complain...she said no more chicken and refused to give us a refund....finally she said ok....

See pics..
author: Johnny C.

description:
Recommended by some Asian friends--I'm glad I listed to them! Great value--large portions, fresh ingredients, good seasoning--we'll be back! 

It's a popular place so be prepared to wait a little.
author: Mj S.

description:
Not sure how I missed posting a review for this place but here it goes.  This is where one of my favorite Chinese joints used to be...Best Panda.  

We tried the following a couple of weeks ago.  

Food = great. Some items are slightly more greasy than others. 

Pork stickers = good flavors and not greasy. $6.98

Spicy salted wings = good. $8.98 

Chicken wonton soup = Good, and one order is plenty for two (or maybe three.) $8.98.

BBQ Pork fried rice = good, not greasy and not overly salted. $8.98.

Mixed vegetables = Not just broccoli (which I love but I know it's cheap) and not full of zucchini (which I dislike but will consume). Dried beancurd Chinese greens, shiitake, beansprouts, broccoli, carrots, napa cabbage and bean thread. One of the better vegetable combinations that I've had. $8.98.

Scrambled eggs with shrimp over steamed rice =  awesome. Simple scrambled eggs with shrimp and scallions (not greasy) over steamed rice.  (I've made return trips for this dish, because it's a comfort meal for me, and the closest to shrimp with (white) lobster sauce that I'll ever get.) $8.98.

Service = friendly.  We've only had take-out here but they are quite friendly and polite. 

Prices = moderate but the portions are quite hearty. Dinner for two came out to $56.29 with leftovers for two more meals!
author: Fannie S.

description: One of my top 3 cantonese restaurants in sf! The food is delicious and the service is fast. The workers are super nice and the prices here are right! I love this place!
author: Ruhjeenuh Z.

description: The food is decent and the portions are huge, great value for your money. Avoid the weekends if possible...otherwise, service is horrible!!
author: Amy H.

description:
Great place to bring your family, 
large portions at reasonable prices. Service is great, unless the restaurant is fully booked. Order the prix fixe family menu, to get the most bang for your $$$.
author: Roland F.

description:
I liked the Rock Cod w/ soft Tofu and the Salty shrimp.  Good portions.  

Service is quick.  The local, elderly Chinese from Richmond district eat here.

Close to Lands End and Legion of Honor, in case you are a tourist.
author: Xs X.

description:
I like this place. They serve delicious Chinese food for decent prices. We have been both for lunch and dinner. Service is good and fast. For dinner and lunch, They give you free house soup which is always a nice on a cold day.  I can't complain about anything at all - this is now my go to Chinese place.

Dishes I recommend :

Honey pepper beef strips 
Black bean clams
Garlic pea sprouts (seasonal)
author: Jannie Q.

description: Well priced, here our family dinner place like their crab meat soup, spicy fish, and fujian rice.
author: Qing L.

description: This is a great little neighborhood Chinese Restaurant with a great selection, fresh ingredients and served hot delish at the right price.  I should give it a five but I've only been once and only had three dishes off of the three plate lunch special.  But can ya believe that the menu has 236 different items!!  I didn't go over the entire menu in detail but just under pork, they have 17 ways you can get it.  It's a fun place and for us, the service was quick and efficient.  Mind you that we went right when it opened on a weekday so maybe that's why it was so quick.  I can imagine that with a packed house and that many different items, some coming out of the tank, it might take a while.  Just cleaning and scaling the live fish would kick it out to 20 mins.  Haha.  My stuff came straight from the refer, to the wok and then to the table.  This is definitely a place to go multiple times to get negotiate a bit thru the menu.  At least they worry more about the food than getting the name right unless they just ran out of space for the R.
author: Wayne K.

description: The food was absolutely wonderful, from preparation to presentation, very pleasing. We especially enjoyed the lobster is really fresh, all the food there have a good portion and fair price. I'm highly recommend this place if you want or dinner.
author: T I.

description: Okay food. Mom likes coming here. They used to have pretty good specials for 4 or 6 family style dinners. Now the family style set dinners are catered for larger groups. The food is okay. Abit too much sodium and oily.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
This is a bit of a go to place for my family and quick lunch because it's in my neighborhood and has great value.  The place can be considered Chinese-y as the food is Cantonese and they have varietal "Live Seafood" with aquariums.  That is important when I'm looking for a family meal.  

I frequent the place often but it may not be a place I drive long distance for.   The food is descent but it can be too starchy occasionally depending on the item or even the days you go (I think head chef is off Mon/Tue as revealed by the server upon my inquiry).

My typical order can be anything from:

Steamed fish   (Live cod or similar)  2-way or 3-way available
Crab   (Scallion/Ginger, Salty egg yolk)
Garlic Seasonal Veggies  (Peasprout, Yam leaf, Chinese Watercress...)
Salt / Pepper Spareribs
Scallion Chicken 1/2 to whole
Steamed Oyster or Surf Clam Vermicelli
Pan-fried noodles
Honey-walnut prawn (a bit small in comparison to other dishes)

Most of the dishes are adequately made and on par for my consideration but not outstanding comparing to some of the high-end places I've been.  However, the values here are great and the portions are pretty big, so I'm not going to complaint.  I've had other dishes too and they seem to be about the same...  a bit unrefined as well.  They are typically semi-busy because of their value and neighborhood status.  I also want to mention they have family meals which is great for medium to large groups (they have lots of big tables).  The service is OK, they can get overwhelmed when busy...  they try, it's casual, not those expectation of fine dinning.  By the way, parking can be a hassle and limited.
author: Steven C.

description:
It's a bargain for unsanitary Chinese food. I have heard of poor reviews about how unclean they are. Thought I would give them a chance. For sure, they disappointed on my to-go order...

 At first, I found  a piece of long hair in my fried rice, meaning no one was wearing hair restraint while preparing the food. 

Second, I scooped out a big piece of plastic....

Ewww.....my appetite and money were gone!

It's up to you if you want to give them a chance. Thought I would share with you what I found...
author: Elm E.

description:
Emperor Taste, you used to be so much better. I don't know if you've changed chefs or are just catering more to white people, but everything is so damn salty. Portions have gotten smaller, and dishes come out in the wrong order. Two fish dishes came out, and the clam-with-oyster-sauce--in-lettuce-wrap appetizer came out at the end. I like how they've changed up the wok-fried crab into a more deep-fried one with calamari, but that's about the only thing that worked in this meal. Even though everything was overly salty, the classic steamed fish was raw at first, and they forgot the soy sauce. Even the e-mein in the lobster was seasoned. Why? There was also this super funky rice dish with the sweet and sour sauce from kung pao pork and egg broth from the soup, all combined onto a plate of fried rice. Really not sure what's going on here.

They also upped their prices. $10 credit card minimum, but that's not really an issue. Who gets under $10 of food at a Chinese restaurant? Empero Taste, you are no longer a good spot to go for dinner.
author: Danny C.

description:
I own the motorcycle shop across the street.  And I am so lucky to have a fantastic restaurant on the same block as me. 

There are a few restaurants near us but this one does it best.   Prices are fair and food is delicious.   The ladies are also very sweet and courteous. 

Did I mention how lucky we are to be neighbors with this awesome Chinese restaurant?
author: Miguel C.

description:
Good food, easy sunday parking, huge portions and good service. 

Skin on the lamb was too much for me but that's on my end, no fault for the restaurant.
author: Asa R.

description:
Came here tonight for my grandfathers 90th birthday! Had a little family reunion going on even though we live within 10 minutes of each other, its rare the family is together all at once with our busy lives. 

Spotted my cousin crossing the street as I was looking for parking and she pointed at one right outside the restaurant. Score! Everyone else had also found very near by street parking so you won't have to worry about that. 

Ordered a variety of dishes but I don't eat meat so my options were limited. I had two bowls of the egg white and shrimp soup. Kind of bland without the white pepper. I also had about 20 of the black bean oysters and a couple of fried shrimps. 

Service was whatever. Better than your usual rude Chinese waitresses I suppose. Had to ask them to change our plates halfway through the meal. I saw them prepare about 7 massive bags of take out so I think this place is popular for that. 

The dessert at the end was the best part especially because no one had bought cake. WTF a birthday with no cake? Apparently it was at the request of my grandfather to not get a cake though. Good thing the yummy red bean soup made up for it!
author: Tiffany V.

description: Food is pretty good and the portions are big.  The restaurant gets quite  busy so go early or make reservations.  We had crab with ginger and scallions, salted fish and chicken fried rice, stirred fried green beans with pork, and lamb and tofu clay pot.  All were very good with the exception of the lamb clay pot.  Would definitely go again!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Come here for my parents' church annual luncheon. Did like family style 10 course meal. We had spareribs, fried rice, soup, crab and lobsters, abalone and bok choy, fish, honey walnut shrimp, clams, and seafood plate. although their food are good and had a lot of flavor but i felt they put a lot of msg on their food. You can get your money worth since you can get a lot on one dish and their price is very reasonable. If you eat too much, you can always go to the beach for a while since the beach is a few blocks away from this restaurant. 
Whenever i do come here, the staffs are always friendly and the service is not bad. The food do come out at a fair time.
author: Julie N.

description: This is my families go to Chinese restaurant in the Richmond District. We know the wait staff and are regulars. Service is what you would expect of a Chinese Restaurant and they definitely are consistent. Their massive menu will always have us trying something different and yet we still love their Staples. If you have a party of 5 or more then make reservations. They packed incredibly quick. Their banquet menus have plenty of food to feed even the most hungry of people. Love love love this place and would always come back
author: Brian H.

description: We came here for dinner and the food was average. The seating is a bit cramped and hard to get in and out to the restroom. The garlic black bean clams were very good. Service is slow: no one ever checks on you after the food arrives. Our empty teapot never got refilled with hot water. The chow fun noodles are very greasy and the crispy honey shrimp was over battered. Not bad for the price but nothing special.
author: Wanda L.

description: This is my go to Chinese food spot. Been coming here since they were Panda country. Good food, friendly staff. Food comes out quick. Their chili condiment is very unique, haven't seen it anywhere else.
author: A B.

description: Relaxing environment, quick serve time and decent portions sizes will have us coming back. Flavors were on par and the entire meal was inexpensive considering we had a 2.5lb crab on the table.
author: Julie L.

description: Ordered what I thought was a vegetarian dish: MaPo Tofu. Got it to go otherwise I would have sent it back. It came with a huge mound of white rice, a decent amount of tofu on top of a bed of pork! I was horrified when I found that!  Not sure if it was how I ordered or what next time I will definitely specify I meat!
author: Gee W.

description:
Parking in this 'hood?
Tough.

Lunar New Year's Eve Dinner?
630.

Divey digs?
Yup.

Pleasant company?
Naturally.

Play pass the baby?
Gimme.

Seafood soup?
OK.

My opinion of the fried pork?
Salty.

Kid's opinion of the fried pork?
"Scrumptious"

Fried chicken dish?
Dry.

Peking duck skin?
Greasy.

Prawn and Walnuts dish?
Delish!

Other dishes?
Forgettable.

Red bean soupy dessert?
Ick.

Wish I was at Kirin instead?
http://goo.gl/rl2P3K
author: Amy C.

description: My boyfriend and I's go to spot when we're craving Chinese food. It's literally across the street from our apartment. Food comes out fast. My boyfriend's go to was the salt and pepper pork chops and mine was the salt and pepper squid (calamari). They were both fried, salty and mixed with tons of pepper and garlic. Always super tasty. Their wonton soup was really yummy as well! We typically got food to go since it's so close to our apartment, but the times we were there the staff was friendly and quick. Looks like a great place for families to have dinner. There was always a ton of people each night eating at the restaurant. There's nothing extremely special about this restaurant, ie. there's no dry fried chicken wings like shanghai house, but its a great alternative if you're not looking to wait in line forever.
author: Rochelle I.

description:
I just had them cater a school lunch for me.  The food was excellent and there was plenty of it too.  It also came hot, not lukewarm.  It literally came down to about $6 per person for a buffet.  Where can you get that?

What we had:

Veggie Chow Mein (ok.  A bit on the wet side especially if you were unfortunate enough to get a scoop from the bottom)
Shrimp Fried Rice (good)
Egg roll (they put vermicelli noodles in it!)
Potsticker (I think these were frozen but still good)
broccoli beef (a fan favorite.  We ran out)
Orange chicken (ditto)
Braised tofu and mushrooms (we got a lot of this left.  Still good but I think there were a lot left cuz some of the kids didn't want it)
Sweet and sour pork - I'm eh on this only because it was a soggy goopy mess.

Overall it was the best bang for our buck.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Good food.
Good service.
Large portions.
 Nuff said.
author: Nuno M.

description: Delish n good portions. Try the fried calamari!  Good selection for family dinners too.  Staff friendly
author: Alberta C.

description:
Went to this Chinese restaurant at last
minute. Was very busy but was seated right away at 6:00 pm.
Westlake soup: *****
Hakka stuffed tofu: *****
salt and pepper pork: *****
Pork belly and preserved vegi: *****
Beef and string beans: ****

Excellent Restaurant 
In the Richmond District
author: B O.

description:
Price (Value): 4 stars
Food (Taste): 5 stars
Service: 4.5 stars
Atmosphere: 4 stars

A great value restaurant in the Sunset if you're willing to travel a bit off the well established roads in the district. Situated on Balboa in a non-descript corner is what is the "NEW" Empero Taste. The original establishment was mediocre or below-average, but under new management for the past year and more, Empero is quickly re-establishing itself as much more service friendly, great-tasting and authentic Chinese cuisine experience.

The prices are great when compared to other Chinese restaurants in the region and the taste is superb, and I eat a lot of Chinese food.

Service has dramatically improved (one of the main reasons why I stopped visiting this place a couple years back) and the atmosphere has grown much more lively with regulars coming back fairly often.

Definitely a place I would re-visit in the future! 5 stars.
author: D K.

description:
I really really want this place to do well..
I know there are too many random Chinese restaurants, but I REALLY like this spot:

- Service is always super friendly! 
- Reasonable prices for lunch or dinner
- Enough variety for the newbie as well as those looking for more authentic flavours
- Some of their special dishes require 48-hr notice, keep that in mind
- They actually grocery shop regularly and only buy good quality ingredients of the week

Ok, so maybe I particularly like them because we're fellow canto-speakers,
but I genuinely like these guys, and the owner always stops by to see how 
things are going. He's old, squinty, and way casual but takes pride in his food!
Their seafood is really fresh and my grandma loves it, which is a plus.

Family lunches always start with a soup/broth and finish with sweet red-bean dessert.
One mein, two meats, two veggies, one claypot, and steam rice all around.
Weekend evenings get insanely busy, so make a reservation if you're determined,
otherwise the wait can be pretty long (as it's normally large groups).

Looking forward to coming back.. next time I'm trying their porridge,
as winter is coming and that's always porridge season!
author: Jade T.

description:
They specialize in large groups and don't seem to be able to scale back portions for individuals.  This is awesome because it means you're going to have food to take home even if you eat a lot.

Oh, and it's cheep.

It might have felt a little strange to be the only non-Asian person in the place, but dang the food was good and could feed an army.
author: Jay F.

description: They came back from the depths of disappearance. They're back with a vengence. The food, the service, the prices all great. Came back to check this place out again and its living up to the new hipe. Had a group of 10, each ordered a dish, full size, plenty of food, walked out less than 10.00 per person. Family style, sharing .... good deals. They have banquet style menu, wah choy - daily specials. I RECOMMEND this place.
author: Dabin L.

description:
We found this place after a long drive and both of us were very hungry. I plan on returning again and again! The food is good,  hot, and plentiful. Oh, and did I mention the prices are cheap ? (Not LA cheap, but SF cheap.) The only thing I would do next time is bring more people--the portions are HUGE! I always need a to-go box.

Empero Taste is located in the Outer Richmond, so parking is not impossible. The restaurant itself is spacious and looks clean. The clientele is by and large Chinese (a good indicator of decent food,  I think.)

I love the simplicity of the food.  I always order the fried rice because it's light and fluffy without all that heavy sauce. Everything I've tried is delicious.
author: JV K.

description:
I've come here just a handful of times even though I frequent the area often. The food is actually pretty good, though nothing that holds my attention. It's exactly what I look for in Chinese food without the heavy greasy lingering feeling afterwards. 

I've ordered the Ying Yang fried rice (must try if you'you've never had it). It's a plain egg rice fried topped with two kinds of sauces : tomato red sauce with onions and chicken & and a white sauce with egg white base, peas and shrimp. Mix the two together or eat each sauce separately, but either way, you won't be sorry! Also ordered garlic eggplant and Mongolian beef (nice medium spice level). My total was $29 for the 3 entrees. 

Parking is relatively easy with lots of residential space.
author: Connie C.

description:
I used to dine here a lot. When this place was called Best Panda. The food was okay. Your typical Chinese food just like all Chinese restaurants.  Then towards The end if Best Panda, The food wasn't as good. And customers started to dwindle.  Then they closed down.

Months later, there was a grand opening. And the place was now called Emperor Taste.  Thinking that it was a grand opening new restaurant I decided to go in and give it a try. We went during lunch time, and we ordered three dishes for $19.99.  The quality is the same, nothing to write home about. Just like all the other Chinese restaurants. I'm not sure if they were serving dim sum. We only got the menu for the dishes.

However, I do notice that this restaurant is run by the same people. The owner who used to run Best Panda was also working there.  He was managing their workers and taking care of the money. 

So this is not a different restaurant. They only change their name from Best Panda, to Imperial tastes. If you been to best panda in the past and remember the quality of food, it is exactly the same now for him. Case.
author: Jack L.

description: My family literally eats here all the time. The food is consistently delicious and quick. Service is very good, especially for a Chinese restaurant. Prices are very reasonable, especially for the portions that they give you. Excellent for a casual night in, a banquet style meal, or a lunch special!
author: Jennifer Hom C.

description:
If you're looking for a cheap, delicious and affordable dinner -- this is the place to be!

BEST shrimp & walnuts ever! And I thought this before I saw the price at the end (I come with my family, so I don't usually order). It was so gooooood! I was shocked, because this is me and my brother's favorite dish which we order all the time, but they made it especially YUMMY here.

I also liked the Yan Yang Fried rice dish, which was sweet & sour pork on one side and egg-like sauce on top of fried rice. It was so good! Try it out if you're goin' for something new.

As default, we always order the fried fish, which is always good. And as for the vegetable dish, the sauteed pea shoots are the best way to go :) (saucy .................yuuum).

When I saw the price at the end for like 5-6 dishes, I was shocked! This is the true definition of one $ on yelp. I was pleased. And we always go for dinner, so I'm not sure about lunch or breakfast, but they give a red bean dessert at the end, which is okay...but it's free ~
author: Mel T.

description:
When I moved into the neighborhood, I thought this would be a convenient place to grab dinner on weeknights.  So at the beginning I would order food to-go. The food is ok. Nothing spectacular. But one time, I ordered clams and I ate clams... and SAND! But soon I noticed their bad practices. 

During the day on a weekday (so less foot traffic), I saw one of the workers out on the street cracking what looked like shells in the gutter. I mean, IN THE STREET. It's almost like they forgot that there was a kitchen where you could do that. So it makes me wonder what other shady stuff they've done with the food. 

I know I can choose whether I eat here or not. But there has been several instances when the restaurant decided the best time to run a loud generator is at 1 AM on a weeknight which without saying, is just rude. And tossing oil in the street? Been there, done that. Without a doubt, this place is cheap for large portions as other reviewers have said but that's because they cut corners and take this neighborhood for granted.
author: Claire H.

description: I dont normally hate on local restaurant near my hood but damm does it really take 20 minutes for salt and pepper spareribs over rice for lunch? Seriously people who walked in 10 minutes after me, got their food before me? I don't wanna sound ungrateful but the food service score of 74% also doesn't help your reputation as a outer Richmond Chinese restaurant.
author: Harry T.

description:
New spot my family choose for my grandma's birthday.  Although the window sign said they have a health rating of 77 the interior dining area looked clean.  Who knows what the kitchen looks like...

The staff was super friendly, the food came out relatively quick and most of the dishes had decent sized portions.  Some looked a little skimpy, like the honey walnuts prawns.  The salt and pepper pork chops pieces had too much fat on them.  Their (over)use of msg will probably prevent me from coming back again unless the family decides to come back as a whole.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
When this place was called Best Panda, we came here about 15 years ago when Kams was shut down for vacation.  I remembered that the place was empty and my youngest daughter and I went there.  However, the staff just ignored us and we finally walked out.  Now that it is called Empero Taste, we thought it might be different.

An associate raved about this place and provided her favorites.  We arrived on a Tuesday evening (5 PM) when there were only one set of customers.  The restaurant is clean and well lit.  We tried to order chow fun, but the waitress said they were sold out.  How can you sell out of chow fun this early in the evening ?  It is like being out of rice and chow fun is a staple.

Finally we ordered some comparison foods -  sizzling rice soup ($6.99), mongolian beef ($7,95), house special chow mein ($6.99), honey sesame chicken ($7.50).  Before we had an opportunity to have much soup, the staff brought out all the dishes.  It seems like they should have waited, but they just dumped it on the table.

The soup had a nice flavor, but really was devoid of anything that would resemble a quality sizzling rice soup, though it did have lots of green onions.  At first they brought the soup, but forgot the rice.  They then brought out 4 squares of deep fried rice and place it into the soup to make it sizzle.  As the waiter ladled the soup, he didn't bother to take the soup spoons out of the bowl.

The mongolian beef lack any sort of "hotness" that you would expect from a dish like this.  Maybe it was made too much for "western taste buds".  It did have nice chunks of yellow and green onions.

The honey chicken consisted of bits of deep fried chicken heavily battered and covered with honey and sesame.  It reminded me of those chicken poppers at fast food restaurants.  As I said, it was mostly batter with only small pieces of chicken.

The house special chow mein was nothing special.  It consisted of mainly noodles with a sprinkling of calamari, red and green onions, chicken and ham pieces and "one" shrimp.

The service is only so-so and they never came back to ask about the food.  Again, this is a series of inadequate Cantonese places that we have tried, regardless of the good intentions of associate recommendations.  Would we come here again?  Probably not, as their are plenty of middling and inadequate Chinese restaurants to chose from.
author: Robert J.

description:
* Food:
o Presentation: Ok. (3/5)
o Temperature: Always hot. (5/5)
o Quality: Great! (4/5)
o Dishes ordered: Egg yolk crab, fried salt & pepper shrimp, diced french style beef, and garlic snow leaf.
o Tastiest dish: Love their egg yolk crab, fried salt & pepper shrimp, diced french style beef, and garlic snow leaf! (5/5)

* Service:
o Attentive: Yes. (5/5)
o Knowledgeable: Ok. (3/5)
o Friendliness: Yes! (5/5)

* Restaurant:
o Atmosphere: This place is almost always packed. Tons of people come here for dinner or big parties for birthday events. (5/5)
o Cleanliness: I'm not sure how clean the kitchen is but the front seems clean. When I walk past their kitchen, it's a bit questionable. (4/5)
o Cost vs. value: Depending on how big your crab is, nothing beats $20 for a 2.5 pound crab. Great price! (5/5)

* Will I revisit restaurant? Yes! It's one of my go-to places for egg yolk crab. :)
author: Mindy - Oishii Moments S.

description:
Dare I say it. Yep. This has got to be the best Chinese restaurant I've been to in a very long time. I was here for a family gathering, and for the first time in years, I ate. For the past few years, whenever we went out, I never ate the food, I sat and picked at the food, but never ate until I was full. My brother and I would come home and eat again after a gathering. This time, I actually ate my share. The food is good, service is... well, you know. 

My only complaint is that the bathroom is disgusting. If you can hold it, do it.
author: Stacy C.

description: From the persective of a vegetarian. Got the mixed veggie stir fried rice noodle. Super tasty, and guaranteed will not die from malnutrition -- unlike other chinese seafood restaurants that attempt making something vegetarian for u (they simply take out the meats and ur left with just noodles, sauce, and onions if ur lucky). My rice noodles had lots of huge chunks of an assortment of 10 types of veggies!
author: Crystal R.

description:
Very average-tasting food, and the most diluted tea I've ever had at a Chinese restaurant.

At least the food came out quickly, and the clams tasted fresh. The place itself feels very modern with a traditional touch, and is also very spacious for groups of at most 10 people. The waiters were also responsive to their customers.
author: Addy Y.

description: This spot is the go to spot with my family whenever I visit San Francisco. We've been loyal customers here since I was young and have watched this restaurant change owners and it's name. The food is decent and the prices are affordable. This place is comparable to any other Chinese restaurant in the Sunset or Richmond District. They have a lunch special where you can choose three entrees for under $20 (comes with soup of the day and unlimited white rice). My family and I always come here because it's close by to our home and the service isn't too shabby. They sure do know how to do business though because most of their dishes are topped with loads and loads of onions and their seafood noodle dishes are almost all noodles. Nonetheless, it's been a family tradition to come here for all our family gatherings or for holidays and we are not one to break tradition. So this place can count on our business for years to come!
author: Amy T.

description:
Love the economy dinner! 

Everything you would expect from a Chinese place. 

Restrooms could be a bit cleaner, but no complaints .
author: One L.

description:
Probably one of my fave go to spots with my fam! 

The service could be a tad better...and the place itself could be a little cleaner, but damnit my fam keeps coming back!

We always get the French style spareribs, flounder, steamed sea bass(only if you can pick the fish--it's super fresh), walnut prawns, popcorn chicken, crispy chicken, clams in black bean sauce and the lobster with the noodles!! Hellla good. 

I think they put msg in their food which I realize now that may be the reason why we keep coming back. Oh well, try it and see for yourself!
author: Clarissa G.

description:
Always great food. 
Come here at least two-three times a year for family 'functions' 
Quick service, friendly staff. 
GREAT food!!
If I lived closer I would be here a lot more.
author: Ryan J.

description:
My family comes here once in a while when we get tired of the same Chinese restaurants in Sunset.  Typical Chinese restaurant with greasy food and  Chinese workers who don't understand you when speaking in English.  

Last week, we had reservations for twelve people and they sat us at a table that sits eight comfortably.  Can you imagine twelve people using chopsticks and poking each other in the eyes?!  To top it off, we ordered the banquet meal and the table didn't come with a lazy Susan.  Are you kidding me?  MOST STRESSFUL DINNER IN MY LIFE!!  Every 30 seconds, "Hey Cheryl, can you pass me the crab in front of you?"  or me asking someone else to pass me something.  Or.... having such a small table and having to find room to put the new plates of food without spilling it on your lap.  We asked for a different table, but it was full house so we asked for a Lazy Susan but the waitress said they had ran out.....

Although parking is rough and the experience can be questionable, the food here is OK and prices are very reasonable.  3 stars for food, 2 stars for service.
author: Cheryl Q.

description: More like three and a half. Good food, attentive service. Still exploring menu, but everyone seems to get the sizzling beef plate. The giant clam with vermicelli/bean thread is killer.
author: E. W.

description:
Make a reservation if you don't want to wait.  This restaurant is located in the middle of a neighborhood so don't be surprised if you're driving past rows of houses.  They recently remodeled, and their prices went up (ie: we usually come in a big family group, and the meal package for 8 people went up $10 from about $69 to $79), which is still an amazing deal!  We also noticed that some of their portions got smaller (especially the Honey Walnut Prawns, which was still delicious, but definitely more skimpy). Sad face.

If you're coming in a big group, I think it's more economical to order from the meal packages in the back of the menu, and add dishes that you want that are not included in the package. ie: We ordered Honey Walnut Prawns and Calamari separately.  

Must haves:
Fried Sand-Dab (you can eat most of the bones!) - THIS IS GOOD!
Calamari
Honey Walnut Prawns

FYI: Rice is not included, and must be ordered separately.

To free up some stomach space after your meal, take a stroll over to Purple Kow (a straight and short walk from Empero), and then proceed fill up that stomach space with some delicious Boba (Roasted Oolong 80% or 100% sweet is good).
author: Melody H.

description:
Best Chinese food you can get for the price.

Also is the best salt pepper squid I've ever had. I think they list it as "Fried Squid" on the menu, but you should reconfirm just in case.
author: Louis W.

description: This place has some really nice fried flounder (according to my grandparents). I couldn't have any because I'm in the middle of my volleyball season. The thing I did enjoy was the giant clam with vermicelli. That was the highlight of the meal. The crab soup is nice and rich compared to other restaurants and is great to lead off the meal. Other than that, all the other dishes are good, but not great. I will certainly come back at some point to have some fried flounder after my season is finished.
author: Ian W.

description:
Upon coming back to San Francisco, one of the things that I was looking forward to most was some great dim sum.  When an old high school friend invited me to lunch at one of her favorites, how could I refuse?  We were looking for Best Panda, but what we got was worst tasting Empero.  Upon walking up, I noticed something peculiar about the sign.  First of all, it seemed to be missing an 'R' to spell "Emperor", but second, the "M" in the sign was mounted backwards!  This was just a prelude to the dumpy dumplings we were about to sit down to.

Empero Taste was having a grand opening special where each of the small, medium, and large plates cost only $1.80, so we decided to order a variety of things to taste.  The problem was that all of my old favorites weren't included in the promotion and cost full price, which was pretty expensive for dim sum.  One of my favorite dishes is the rice crepes with fresh shrimp, which we ordered at full price.  After the first bite into the shrimp, I noticed something fishy, literally.  These were definitely not fresh shrimp and tasted of it.  All of the other dishes, including the chicken feet, spare ribs in black bean sauce, xiaolongbao, har gow, and siu mai were all a bit dry and none of the dishes seemed very fresh or well seasoned.

All in all, I was extremely unimpressed by the food and service of this restaurant.  Even the baiting by the $1.80 promotion is not enough to bring me back.  When I go to dim sum, I like to gorge myself with all of the great dim sum flavors and great selection, but sadly, neither of those could be found and enjoyed at Empero Taste.  If you're in town looking for a great deal, I highly suggest going somewhere else.  Sometimes sacrificing quality for cost can net you some good deals, but you won't find the benefit for the cost here.

Food: 5/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description:
You want good and cheap dim sum?  Come here!  

I have never been here nor was I ever planning on coming to this part of SF only because I stick to Union Square, Nob Hill, Chinatown, Japantown, Mission District, and North Beach whenever I'm up there but a spontaneous adventure w/ my friend led us to this little gem.  My friend has been here before and he decided to drive an hour just for lunch because this place offers decent and quick service, good food, generous portions, and it's so damn cheap!  

I am not eating meat today per the Lunar calendar so I ordered: plain soy sauce chow mein ($4.95), an order of the stuffed mushrooms, an order of deep fried tofu w/ jalapenos, and Chinese donuts rice roll.. and a Diet Coke, of course.  My friend ordered: salted fish fried rice, half a steamed chicken, xiu mai, har gow, and pork buns.. a regular Coke.

11 items total including the drinks came to just $42.  

How freaking awesome was that?
author: Tram N.

description: We were in San Fran for vacation and we literally followed our noses to this restaurant.  We had the spicy salted chicken wings, sizzling rice & seafood soup and pork belly with greens and the French basil pork chops.  (I don't see the pork belly or the pork chops on the menu online at menupages.com but that's what we had.)  Everything was outstanding.  Seriously, the best Chinese food I've ever had.  This is significant because I'm normally sort of take it or leave it with Chinese food.  If I lived here we would go regularly.  All of it was delicious but my favorite was the pork chops.
author: Angell V.

description:
$4.99 lunch, heaping portions and free house soup (a delicious broth, usually with carrots and pork bones--SO DELICIOUS). I go for lunch with my gramps pretty regularly, and he loves the beef brisket with won ton soup. There are tons of variations of won ton soup, chock full of goodies. Also lots of good rice plates to choose from.

Came for dinner here once and got the $78 meal (6 people). I love when I get the chance to order this "meal" because you get a bit of everything. Off the top of my head, it comes with house soup (seafood and tofu), black bean clams, fried chicken with shrimp chips, peking spareribs, salt & pepper prawns, Chinese bacon and cabbage, mustard greens, fried flounder and ginger-green onion crab. It was so tasty, the crab was sweet and tender. They gave tons of clams and the clams were very meaty. They were also nice about substitutions; we traded some of the deep fried dishes out. Plus they changed our plates out twice (because it was banquet, plus tons of shells from the crab).

I should mention that for being a Chinese seafood hole-in-the-wall type restaurant, the ambiance is rather clean (kinda cold, if you get cold easily bring a jacket) and the service is pretty good. I would absolutely take guests here for a cheap, authentic Chinese meal.
author: Kris Q.

description:
This year, Chinese New Year (CNY) and Valentine's Day all landed on the same day, a Sunday. One thing was for sure, most restaurants were going to be full. 

For this reason, our extended families decided to hold their CNY dinners weeks after the actual CNY date. However, we still brought the kids to see their grandparents the day before CNY. We were pretty full from eating dim sum earlier in the day, and my in-laws were also full from having a buffet for lunch.  We weren't thinking of having dinner.

The kids, however, were hungry. We thought most places would be full that evening, but my mother in law called this place (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ufEYEDMaaoiFAxw81IlBAw?select=7MZ2pC86Vv0INIm5aEr5rw). Lo and behold, they said a table would be freeing up in 10 minutes, and to get our butts over there to claim it. 

After scoring a good parking spot, we entered the restaurant, which was packed. One of the servers showed to a small round table that was perfect for the six of us. 

The adults weren't really hungry, so we didn't order anything special or fancy for the kids. (The lobster noodles the other tables ordered, however, looked very good!) 

Our order: 
-Braised beef tendon with turnips in a clay pot (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ufEYEDMaaoiFAxw81IlBAw?select=VxW1I-yXONml627FMDsxLg): arrived at the table bubbling. Nice sauce that was perfect with rice. There was more definitely more tendon than meat, but was OK.

-Steamed Chinese Broccoli with braised chicken (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ufEYEDMaaoiFAxw81IlBAw?select=Yh82bmcddnoa-PrjIgYaiA):  The broccoli was good, with no bitter taste.

-Soft tofu stir-fried with beef and snap peas:  This was ordered at the request of my youngest.  A generously sized dish, lots of cubed tofu, and more importantly for my daughter, very saucy to eat with rice.

-Sweet and Sour Spareribs (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ufEYEDMaaoiFAxw81IlBAw?select=L92NZHSqXGs-ilaQSwdZeA):  Stir-fried with pineapple and onions.  OK

-Dry Fried Beef Chow Fun (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ufEYEDMaaoiFAxw81IlBAw?select=9QxRKxZ5LkqRWWwxHQ-WTg):  this was ordered at the request of my oldest daughter.  Not bad, not too greasy.  Pretty generous with the beef.

Very generous portions for each of the dishes.  We had so much we had a lot of leftovers to take back.

My father-in-law was quite pleased:  only $40 with tip.  Overall, not bad, considering we were able to get table on this busy night.  Great prices.  Will I come back?  Maybe.
author: Steve L.

description:
Although Chinese restaurants are a dime a dozen in the Richmond, it's hard to find a place that I like and that hasn't been hyped through the roof.  Empero Taste is one of these places.  Not to mention it has an incredibly affordable menu!

What I would order here:
Walnut Shrimp
Salt and Pepper Pork

Lunch specials are $4.50, comes with soup, and are not limited to the weekdays.  Serving size is relatively generous as well.  Lunch for 7 came out to be $7 per person including tax and tip.

If the rumors about this place closing are true, I will be sorely disappointed.
author: Fei L.

description:
Empero Taste's kingdom-sized portions catapult it to the forefront of options when dining on the cheap.

The Salt and Pepper Spareribs are evenly battered and appropriately cooked, lending a desirable crisp to each bite of the still-juicy meat.  The seasoning is just salty enough to cause immediate anticipation for the next bite, but not overly rich to perpetuate an endless search for water refills.  The mountain of white rice is more than proportional to the heaping pile of meat.

Even the complementary soup, which is often an obvious leftover dump at the typical Chinese restaurant, is flavorful and contains identifiable ingredients.

The service is fine, and the bill under $10.  Will consider again to satisfy greasy, Chinese rice plate cravings!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Visited Empero Taste on Friday night, March 20, 2015 with mom just to give them another try as another excuse hoping they were good again as I hope they were after my first experience on December 15, 2014 which was a friday night which I'll start with first. Order Dried Beef Chow Fun, they said probably hor fun all sold out and went to kitchen and came back a minute later and it wasn't and did the Mandarin/Peking Spare Ribs. Both were good, Empero Taste calls the Spare Ribs actually baked. Lots of meat, and the pork chops were meaty. the house soup came in two large containers. Ordered another Mandarin/Peking Spare Ribs as takeout for the Toastmasters club party the next night. One thing strange with their Peking Spare Ribs is that at the restaurant, it's fall off the bone but the leftovers at home does not taste as good as the other leftovers. Even the one at the party wasn't as good as the restaurant. Two waitresses even pack the leftovers for us and bagged it with the takeout order, unseen at any chinese restaurant. We had to wait for a table as it was very busy.

February 21, 2015 which was basically the 3rd day of Chinese New Year. It was busy with lots of take outs, had to wait for table. When we finally got the table, no one cleaned the table even after 20 minutes. So the customer in the next table who knew them helped clean and setup the table and brought us menus. Cannot even find someone to take the order after 20 minutes so basically write the numbers of the items wanted and handed it to the front desk. House soup which was hair sized seaweed, dried oysters, water chestnuts came in another 15 minutes. Then came the House Jeen Mein, the gravy was watery so all the eating plates were flooded so basically the jeen mean became a chow mein again with all that water making the noodles soggy. The fookin fried rice was okay but not much flavor. The Mandarin/Spare Ribs was basically meat with lots of bone and did not taste anything like the one from December 14, 2014. and finally the honey walnut prawns were okay. We took the rice home but they only gave us the box without the free bag. 

So on the Friday night of March 20, 2015, decided to give them another chance thinking it must be them being too busy Chinese new year. Arrived at 7:00PM and the restaurant was all empty except for small tables were full. They told us to sit anywhere and gave us the 10 person table and the other ones were still empty. Same waitress as the first time. Ordered Beef Hor Chow Fun but they said hor fun all sold out, so either take chow mein or jeen mein. I said chow mein and they asked thin or thick noodles, I said thin and asked them for the price as there is no beef chow mein on the menu and they said same price as beef hor chow fun. and then ordered Salt & Pepper Pork Chops instead just to try it. Chow mein came, it did not have much meat and lacks flavor. Then came the Salt & Pepper Pork Chops, there was only the Jalapeno peppers sliced but you cannot find any red pepper flakes or salt crystals. The pork chops had no flavor at all, not spicy nor even a hint of salt. and just like the February event, the meat is full of bones, unlike the December event. So something tells me that either they changed the chef's or they changed both the chef's and the owner. I was checking yelp earlier today but the reviews are still good, probably because the people ordered stuff like shrimp sauce and pork belly, I don't know how anyone can mess that up Oh, I forgot to mention the house soup came in a big bowl, it was water cress except the water cress was rough as other than the leaves, it was stiff and you can't even eat it. We took the pork chops hope and they only provided a box without a bag and said they would bring the dessert sweet soup. The soup never came even after 30 minutes so we just left and no employee was even in the dining room(s). The restaurant was pretty empty on this friday night and they had less people working than in December 2014.  Seems like Yan Yan Seafood Restaurant is better if you exclude the December 2014 visit as that one was more good and bigger than Yan Yan's.
author: Vincent P.

description: Those of you who live in the Richmond might remember the fanfare that accompanied the opening of the Best Panda  restaurant on Balboa and the long waiting lines. The restaurant deserved the attention as it served high quality, tasty Cantonese cuisine in a pretty quiet residential setting next to the ocean as the beautiful sea breeze and fog rolled in. The chilly nights were magical as you stepped out after eating a killer meal, full, satisfied and happy. Well the original spirit of Best Panda lives and continues on intact in Empero Taste, which is basically the remodeled, updated, Best Panda, with a new name reflecting the passing of ownership from father to son in the same family. (So I was told by one of the wait staff. ) The food is just as good, cooked as well, and with many of Beat Panda's signature cooking styles and best dishes. In fact, some of the dishes are arguably even better than they ever were. I'm also happy to report that Empero Taste also maintains the reasonable price structure that always existed, including the lunch specials. Killer food, great taste. Good prices. What more could you ask for? If you come for dinner, try the three specials plus soup and rice for $20 and make sure that one of your choices is the "Fried half chicken". It's wicked delicious and after you eat it, you'll say to yourself, "dang that dude on yelp really knows how to eat. " (and if you don't say that, then YOU don't know how to eat! Hahaha jk jk don't get pissed. I know, to each his own....,but seriously, I think you'll like it. ;-)
author: George F.

description:
When you come here, you will eat like an empero...whatever that may be.

Good food, attentive service, fit our dinner party of 30+ with ease. Everything was pretty solid. The pork chops were nice and salty, just the way I like 'em!

My tummy gives Empero Taste...4 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description: A nice chinese restaurant to bring people. I think this is one of the cleaner chinese restaurants that I have been to. The service is quick. However, I did not like that this chinese restaurant does not have dim sum. I will probably come back with my family for dinner. I normally always get one of the family deals. I think the price is good for the food.
author: Jason L.

description:
Went here after the Ski and Snowboard festival.

After a long day, we were hungry. Friend took us here and although there was not much around the area, this place was PACKED.

We waited about 30 minutes for a table for 4.

That was the only long time we had to wait, because after that service was FAST. I have to commend the staff, especially at a Chinese place, because from what I've experienced Chinese places have rude service. Everyone here was nice.

We ordered the meal for 4, which started at $38, but changes depending on changes that you may do.

We had Beef Tofu Soup, Walnut Shrimp, House Special Fried Rice, Seafood Crispy Noodles, Clams, and Spareribs. Some sweat Mung Beat dessert was included.

Everything was tasted good. Greasy of course, but that is all part of Chinese food. HAH! Probably had a bunch of MSG, but the numerous free Monster drinks from the Ski and Snowboard festival offset that.

If your in the area, looking for some Chinese food, check them out. 

Oh, why only 4 stars? Because it taste just like the many other Chinese restaurants I've tasted, there has to be one that WOWs me for the full rack of stars.
author: Eugene N.

description: Food is what you would expect. Consistent chinese food. I reccomend the the yin yang fried. The best of two worlds in one reasonable priced dish service was nice but our rice came last after our entrees and we had to ask for it a couple time. Overall not bad, not great.
author: victor l.

description: Come here about once a month with my co-workers.  Staff are always very friendly.  Food is inexpensive. Their salt & pepper calamari and salt & pepper ribs are really good.  In addition, this is what we usually order and all are very good: pea sprouts with garlic, deep fried flounder, beef chow fun, shrimp with walnuts, lobster low mein, fukien fried rice.  They can accommodate large parties cuz they have those round tables for 10 people.  Easy to get a table during lunch.  Dinner is a bit more crowded.
author: VC D.

description:
Been here to eat off and on since it switched over from Best Panda.  The lighting and interior is much improved.  No more sticky floors and grimy walls.

As stated by other yelpers, portions are very generous and food comes hot.  Order wo choy or a la carte.  Because it is a Chinese restaurant, the entrees all come at once.  They must have several huge woks in the kitchen.  No fine dining experience here.

Yes, it's true.  Sometimes they run out of chairs, especially if large parties are there to celebrate special occasions.

Beware - the HVAC is set very cold.  You must wear warm clothing or risk freezing.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I'd walk the length of Geary to eat here...wait, they're on Balboa, and I only walked from Arguello and Geary, but that definitely worked up an appetite.

Service was friendly. I ordered in a mix of Cantonese and English and they not only got the order right, I received a Cantonese-ordering bonus of the house soup (a generous serving) and tong sui dessert soup.  The house soup and tong sui were pretty standard, neither bad nor exciting. 3 stars each. Well, 3.5 for the tong sui.

The egg surface frog was wonderful in it's lightly fried saltiness. I am not a big fan of salted food but this was the bomb. 5 stars

They were accommodating enough to prepare a half-order of gailan (Chinese broccoli) in garlic sauce. It was perfectly al dente and just the slightest bit bitter, as is normal for gailan. Not only that, they charged me half of the full price for the half order - most places would tack on a dollar. 4 stars for the gailan itself

Rice was moist, but not too moist.

Portion sizes good. Clean rest room.

Would return if I was west of Arguello.

Definitely good for groups, with quite a few big round tables and set dinners on the menu.
author: Charles B.

description: 3.5 ! Not bad. Came here with bf's family to celebrate his bday dinner. It's not bad. Generous portions. Service was fast. Food was decent. Would come back - had a ton of left overs. really liked the honey beef cubes :)
author: Kristina L.

description: I've been here plenty of times, dining in and ordering out. Their crispy fried chicken is my favorite dish.  Others rave about there sea snails in black ban sauce.  However I'm not a sea snail slurping type of guy.  Anyways, I'm not sure why I haven't given it a review in the past..maybe because  I gotten stomach aches after eating here in the and really tried to avoid this place. However, others that dined with me felt fine afterwards.  Maybe it was just me.  The last time  it turned out quite well.  I didn't have a stomach ache and was able to accommodate 3 tables on a very busy night.  (after the Blue Grass festival in GG Park)
author: S F.

description:
Empero Taste has re-opened for business under new management and new staff. We had lunch there today--3 courses of your choice from a select menu plus soup and rice for 19.99.  We opted for quail (6 halves), mixed vegetables, Mandarin ribs.
Food was delicious; servings were ample.  Our doggy bag is tonight's dinner.

Service was prompt and courteous.  They do not serve dim sum.

Rice plates start at $5.50 with some at $6.50.  We plan to try these the next time we go.
author: el h.

description: Friends recommended Empero Taste as it was one of their favorite restaurants to eat in and take out.  We went with their recommendations.  This restaurant makes the best sizzling rice seafood soup. The sizzling rice texture was puffed perfectly and the soup was so flavorful.  The steam egg with clam, sweet and sour chicken, calamari, and vegetables were all so delicious.  All dishes were flavorful and edible, not full of onions as many restaurants tend to do. The service was excellent.  The teapot was always full and dishes came out quickly.  Prices were all very reasonable for the portions they serve.  Will definitely be returning to eat in or ordering to go soon.
author: Joanne L.

description:
chinese food isn't the healthiest... but it shouldn't be super greasy either! i have such a huge issue with greasy food! other than the grease, the food was decent.

came here for dinner to celebrate a friend's birthday this past weekend.. five minutes after our order was placed, the dishes came flying out so quickly, there was no more room on our table for the other dishes that hadn't come out yet! 

pricing pretty much compares to all the other chinese restaurants around. one thing i must say... parking is sucky.
author: Ann T.

description:
Large portions. Above-average taste. Good prices. Above-average service, especially from Jenny who I think is the manager? This place (and the cooking) is quite similar to Bay Fung Tong which closed down some years back from it's Balboa st location (but still has a restaurant in Oakland uptown)....so the emphasis is on seafood!

This family-style restaurant is wonderful for their 3 dishes for $19.99 deal (including soup and unlimited rice!). Favorites are the Hakka style tofu (deep fried soft tofu with a meat stuffing in an amazing sauce), black pepper chicken, sweet/sour rock cod fillet, salt/pepper spareribs or squid, eggplant with fish cake, and their fried flounder in soy sauce. They pour your tea and occasionally even give freebies like cream cheese wontons. And, they'll give you a hot dessert at the end of the meal (with things like white fungus...better than it sounds!, red bean soup, etc). 

Their panfried noodle dishes are "eh"....the family style dishes are where it's at.
author: Charlie D.

description:
Decent, affordable Chinese food. 

My family of 14 used to eat dinner here a lot. They have pretty decent "banquet-style" Chinese food and a lot of pre-fixe meals to choose from. Some memorable dishes are their salt and pepper calamari and the long neck clam in a shell. They have affordable $4.95 rice plates and $4.95 entrees. We also usually get complimentary dessert soups after dinner. 

Tables are very close together so the restaurant can get cramped when it's packed. Service is traditional, Asian-style-straight-to-the-point. Bathrooms aren't the cleanest but do-able. I see a lot of people do take-out and with the restaurant usually almost at full-capacity, I'd recommend it for Chinese food.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Me: "I would like shrimp with black bean sauce"
Waitress: "No, only clam black bean sauce"
Me: "Well, you have shrimp with lobster sauce"
Waitress: "No, only clam black bean sauce"
Me: "Okay, you have clam with black bean sauce and you have Shrimp with Lobster Sauce, I would like Shrimp with Black Bean Sauce"
Waitress: "Extra" 
Me: "Okay"

You are paying for the table cloth, my not very good "Shrimp with Black Bean Sauce" was fair, too much starch.  $13 dinner, just the one entre and a glass of water.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6wtfNE4z6a8

Blues Brothers:
Mrs. Murphy: May I help you boys? 
Elwood: You got any white bread? 
Mrs. Murphy: Yes. 
Elwood: I'll have some toasted white bread please. 
Mrs. Murphy: You want butter or jam on that toast, honey? 
Elwood: No ma'am, dry. 
[Mrs. Murphy gives him a look, then turns to Jake] 
Jake: Got any fried chicken? 
Mrs. Murphy: Best damn chicken in the state. 
Jake: Bring me four fried chickens and a Coke. 
Mrs. Murphy: You want chicken wings or chicken legs? 
Jake: Four fried chickens and a Coke. 
Elwood: And some dry white toast please. 
Mrs. Murphy: Y'all want anything to drink with that? 
Elwood: No ma'am. 
Jake: A Coke. 
Mrs. Murphy: Be up in a minute
author: Mark W.

description:
We came here today for dinner because we got invited over to this restaurant.  It is located in the Richmond neighborhood of San Francisco, and you can see the Pacific Ocean from the front of the street.  However, the weather was chilly even on this July evening.  The neighborhood location is nice but parking is limited to street parking.

The restaurant looks clean and recently remodeled.  Service was great and efficient.  Food tasted very good - it is authentic Cantonese.  The fried squid was good but a little greasy.  Portions are generous - great for leftovers.  Prices were very reasonable.   

They were advertising dim sum for $1.80 a dish; therefore, I might want to try it the next time I am in the city.

A great neighborhood restaurant with a lot of locals folks dining.
author: Bill F.

description:
pretty good. 

we missed the dim sum lunch. so we ordered regular items.

losbter lo mein was HUGE! 
corn soup was yummy
had some sweet and sour spare ribs? i dont know what they are called in english but it was pretty good too.
author: Erica L.

description:
One of the volunteer gardening groups that I'm active with has this obsession with Best Panda.  I've always tagged along for the company, but I hated Best Panda because it was always cheap food that tasted cheap inside a dirty restaurant.

After spending a Saturday morning cutting down ivy and blackberry vines from the big trees around North Lake one of our team leaders suggested that we return to that spot on 42nd Avenue and Balboa Street for lunch.  We were all quite surprised that the space is now Empero Taste.  One of the guys peered into the window; the restaurant was pretty busy at the time.  We decided to go in and give it a try.

Our group of 15 broke apart to take two separate round tables as half of our group wanted to dine family style while the other half wanted to just order individual plates.  The big dining room is partitioned into two parts and we had a room all to ourselves.  I sat down with the group ordering individually mostly because I was one of the last people in, and I didn't know what was going on.

The service started out pretty bad.  We had two big tables and the waiter left us with only one regular menu and one dim sum menu for each table.  It took the waiter over fifteen minutes after we were seated before he brought us three more menus.  A waitress showed up to take our orders a short time later.  The thick large format menu is about six pages big.  The dim sum menu is very extensive too printed on a one-sided sheet of paper.  You simply check off the quantities of your selections and submit the sheet of paper to the waitstaff.  I wanted chow fun, but the waitress said they were already out of fun.  It was only 1:30 PM, and out of fun already?!  I selected the Seafood Pan Fried Noodles instead.

The service began to pick up also.  While we waited for our food the waiters and waitresses kept our tea pots full and refilled our glasses of ice water quickly.  The foods came out of the kitchen at a hurried pace starting first with the dim sum orders, then the rice plates and finally the chow mein orders.  With the exception of the dim sum every selection was large portioned.  I knew our group worked up an appetite because everyone dug into their food.  My selection was one of the last plates out of the kitchen and it was very good.

The Seafood Pan Fried Noodles had firm medium-sized shrimps, tender calamari and huge scallops along with a bit of carrot, a few straw mushrooms and some very tender stalks of bok choy in a light gravy served over a huge bed of thin crispy fried noodles that surprisingly had very little oily residue.
